thread.title: New Benghazi hearings unlikely to fully answer key questions
thread.title_full: New Benghazi hearings unlikely to fully answer key questions

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: New Benghazi hearings unlikely to fully answer key questions
text:
Thursday’s reopening of congressional hearings into the 2012 fatal attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, promises to produce high political theater, as Republicans try to embarrass then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, as well as President Obama. Beyond the partisan squabbling, the hearings will seek answers to key policy questions concerning why the U.S. was in Benghazi in the first place and whether the death of Ambassador Christopher Stevens and three other Americans at the compound could have been prevented.
Yet even after eight investigations, 32 hearings and 70,000 pages of documents produced for various committees, these questions may never be fully answered.
With Republicans and Democrats so polarized and a new presidential election so close, committee members “are not even close to being on the same page,” said Joseph Wippl, a 30-year operations officer and manager at the CIA who now teaches at Boston University. “They’ll circle the wagons and protect their sides (and) the president, but I don’t think they’ll reach any results.”
USA TODAY
Hillary Clinton faces House Benghazi panel
Here are the key questions sought by the committee and the answers to date:
Why did the U.S. have a compound in Benghazi despite the security risks?
In the months preceding the attack, Benghazi had been the site of a string of terrorist attacks against other Western diplomatic missions as militias linked to al-Qaeda became more violent. The State Department ordered Ambassador Stevens to prepare for a permanent post in Benghazi. Clinton hoped to announce the new office during a visit to the Libyan capital, Tripoli, later that year, according to testimony by Stevens’ deputy, Gregory Hicks.
Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee said in their report on the attacks that White House officials "failed to comprehend or ignored" deteriorating security conditions in Libya. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said the administration's "preference for a 'soft footprint' was part of the reason for what took place" in Benghazi.
The special mission in Benghazi bolstered U.S. support for Libya’s democratic transition by engaging with leaders in eastern Libya, the birthplace of the revolt that overthrew former leader Moammar Gadhafi, according to the State Department's Accountability Review Board. Stevens knew and accepted the risks because he believed in his mission, Clinton testified.
ONPOLITICS
Clinton's Benghazi testimony: How to watch
Why did the State Department deny requests for more security at the compound?
Stevens had warned of a worsening security situation and had asked repeatedly for more security, up until the day he was killed. His requests were denied. A 16-member U.S. special forces contingent in Tripoli was reduced four, and its mission changed from embassy security to training Libyan forces. The Accountability Review Board blamed denials of Stevens' requests on four high-ranking State Department officials, citing "systemic failures and leadership and management deficiencies." Clinton said requests for more security never reached her desk. The department also had limited funds for security, which Clinton blamed on congressional budget cuts.
What actions did the U.S. government take during the attacks to protect U.S. personnel?
CIA security personnel stationed at a separate facility in Benghazi raced to the diplomatic outpost within 20 minutes of the attack. They exchanged fire with attackers, rescued State Department personnel and fought their way back to the CIA outpost. There, they continued to fight during sporadic fire and two separate attacks. A joint team of CIA and military officers flew from the Libyan capital, Tripoli, to Benghazi to help evacuate U.S. personnel. They arrived at the CIA annex shortly before a mortar attack there that killed CIA security officers Tyrone Woods and Glen Doherty.
The U.S. military also directed a drone to fly from Derna to Benghazi, where it stayed during much of the night. Other Air Force assets and ground troops stationed in Europe were not in position to respond in time, according to then Secretary of Defense Leon Panetta.
The House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, which looked at the intelligence community’s role in the incident, found no evidence of a “stand down order” regarding the rescue of diplomats under fire, or that available air cover was denied. The November 2014 report countered claims made by Republican lawmakers in other investigative committees. It cleared the CIA of any wrongdoing, but said “mistakes were made” in the writing of talking points explaining the attack days after it happened.
What was the administration’s explanation for the attack and how did it change?
Talking points prepared by the CIA, State Department and the White House explaining the attack, blamed it in part on “extremists” and said it was “spontaneously inspired” by protests in Cairo and elsewhere. Susan Rice, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations at the time and now Obama’s national security adviser, used the talking points in Sunday talk show appearances to explain what happened to the public.
Emails obtained by previous investigations showed that the CIA initially blamed the attacks on known terrorists linked to al-Qaeda. References to terrorism were later removed after the White House assigned Clinton aide Jake Sullivan to work with then-CIA Deputy Director Mike Morell to finalize the initial talking points on Benghazi.
An email sent by Ben Rhodes, Obama's deputy national security adviser for strategic communications, to White House officials said Rice's talk show appearances should "underscore that these protests are rooted in an Internet video, and not a broader failure of policy" and "reinforce the president and administration's strength and steadiness in dealing with difficult challenges."
USA TODAY
Senator: E-mails show how Benghazi story shaped
Republicans, such as Sen. Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, said those talking points downplayed the role of terrorism to protect Obama's anti-terrorism credentials weeks before a close presidential election.
The White House said it relied on the best intelligence available at the time, and when better intelligence arrived, the story was clarified.
Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-S.C., chairman of the special House committee created to investigate the 2012 attacks on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi, Libya, speaks with reporters on Capitol Hill on Sept. 10, 2015. (Photo: AP Photo, Cliff Owen)
